intro.desc: I'm an aspiring software developer and an enthusiast of computer science and programming. I have spent the past four years earning a Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science to satisfy my long-running fascination with computers and to build functional skills I can use in a career. With the time I've spent in college I have learned that I am effective at dedicating myself to filling gaps in my knowledge as I encounter them. My eagerness to impress and create drives my motivation to get better at everything I do.

bio1.desc: The courses for my computer science major introduced me to the fundamentals of a broad range of computer science principles and practices. On top of that, I discovered how important it is to be relentless if your goal is to understand something.

degree1.header: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

bio2.desc1: Outside of computers and programming I like to be in the outdoors. It can be a solo adventure to a new fishing spot, a few friends on a camping trip or boogie boarding in the freezing Pacific ocean-- and I'll be happy.
bio2.desc2: At home, if I'm not working on coding projects I like to read, draw, or build. Generally I prefer to spend my time either making something or moving around.

experience.intro: My work and programming experience includes code collaboration with peers, designing and building computer science course material, IT troubleshooting on a Linux infrastructure, and lots of pizza.

exp1.desc: My general responsibilities were to present short lectures on data structures to lower-level computer science students and be available during labs to help debug or answer conceptual questions.
list: Presenting and explaining data structure concepts to groups of students in labs
Guiding individual students to solutions for programming problems using C++
Developing and maintaining C++ code bases for use in computer science labs
Coordinating lab and lecture materials development with project management software
Proctoring student exams and coding proficiency demonstrations
Training new employees with debugging exercises and code discussions

exp2.desc: My participation in the Capstone project got me introduced to git workflows, front-end technologies and frameworks, and the beauty of collaboration.
list: Developing an interactive web application using Node.js and React.js with TypeScript
Data modeling for a graph data structure implemented with an MVC architecture
Scrum-like collaborative procedures with a team of peers
Collaborating with continuous integration using git and GitLab with CI/CD
Researching unfamiliar technologies for use in project development

exp3.desc: As a member of The Computer Action Team -the organization responsible for the technical infrastructure of Maseeh College of Engineering and Computer Science- I learned how to listen to user's describe their IT issues and respectfully guide them to solutions. Much of our day-to-day responsibilities involved writing and running scripts in a Linux environment to gather information or solve problems.
list: Working directly with MCECS students and faculty for IT troubleshooting
Collaborating on revisions to technical documentation and website content
Attending weekly informational presentations on IT subjects

exp4.desc: In this job I learned how to cooperate with my peers and communicate clearly and efficiently with customers. My time in a position of authority taught me how to respectfully interact with subordinates to maintain an awareness and coordination of time-sensitive tasks.
list: Overseeing and delegating essential duties to staff of up to eight
Regularly communicating with upper-management and accounting staff
Diffusing confrontational interactions among staff or patrons
Ensuring product quality in a fast-paced environment

skills.intro: I am very open to learning new technologies and using best practices when coding and developing. My curiousity motivates me to learn unfamiliar technologies and dev strategies, but my intent to be an asset to my employer motivates me to hone the skills I've got.

skill1.desc: C, C++, Python, Java, HTML, CSS, TypeScript/JavaScript, Bash Script, Rust, SQL

skill2.desc: Linux, Git, GDB, SQLite, PostreSQL, JSON, Regex

skill3.desc: C++ STL, React, NodeJS, Bootstrap, jQuery/AJAX

skill4.desc: Vim, VS Code, IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm

work.intro: I tend to take on personal projects to gain some exposure to different languages, libraries or frameworks. The work listed below range from an interactive web application to command-line utilities.

proj1.desc1: An SPA web application for visualizing the effects of an individual's influence in a complex environment of personalities.
proj1.desc2: The project was built with React on Node supported with graphics and animation using Konva. We used an MVC architecture to organize our data structure interactions. Our development strategy was to use CI/CD where we each took on different development roles.
proj1.desc3: My contributions included implementation of a weighted, directed graph interface, modeling simpler data structures, animation rendering, and of course, debugging anything I could.

proj2.desc1: A command-based note-taking utility designed for people who spend a lot of time with a terminal open.
proj2.desc2: With qnot the user can quickly add a tagged note to a local SQLite database, straight from the command line without opening an interface. Notes can also be created and edited with the user's default text editor or imported from existing files.
proj2.desc3: Although qnot makes it easy to add tagged notes with a single command from the Linux prompt, it also comes with a robust interface that enables many ways of retrieving and managing notes. Users can gather by tag or search the title and body of notes for keywords. Qnot also supports easily selecting multiple notes for exporting, merging, and batch deleting. A built-in, keyword-based help command allows users to figure out exactly how to use a particular qnot feature, or to understand general usage.

proj3.language: React, Node, JavaScript, HTML, CSS, JSON
proj3.desc1: The site you're on now! This began as a final project for a web development class but I have continued its development as a portfolio.
proj3.desc2: This SPA was build on Node using React and Framer Motion for the UI and React Router to handle routing. Check out the README on the repo for a full list of dependencies and resources used.

proj4.desc1: A text-based game of solitaire playable in a command-line. Not yet completed!

proj5.desc1: A toy program to get some familiarity with Golang and take advantage of an opportunity to use a pun. It is a simple utility for decoding a string as morse code. Users can also customize which characters to consider 'dots' and 'dashes' for the purpose of finding secret messages in long strings of random text.
proj5.desc2: Uses a hard-coded binary tree structure to interpret strings then outputs what was decoded.

proj6.desc1: This is the repo for my answers to coding practice questions from various sources. Currently it contains a Roman numeral converter, a bubble sort implementation, a ransom note decoder, and a sliding window comparison.
